stages.title: Threat Assessment
stages.description:
**[BIO-DEFENSE AGENCY - INTELLIGENCE BRIEFING]**

Welcome to Phase 2 of your training. Until now, you've been monitoring internal failures (homeostasis). But the biggest threats to Host Alpha come from EXTERNAL invaders: pathogens.

Your new mission: Learn to identify different types of pathogens, understand their tactics, and classify them by threat level.

activities.scenario:
Two people in your office are sick:

**Person A:** Has a cold (runny nose, cough, sneezing). Started feeling sick 2 days ago.

**Person B:** Has diabetes (manages blood sugar with insulin). Has had this condition for 10 years.

**The Question:** You don't want to get sick. Who should you avoid sitting near?
activities.question: Which person poses a contagion risk to you?
options: Person A (cold) ‚Äî I could catch it
Person B (diabetes) ‚Äî I could catch it
Neither ‚Äî office air conditioning kills all germs
activities.explanation:
**Correct Answer: Person A (cold)**

The key distinction is between:

**INFECTIOUS diseases:**
- Caused by PATHOGENS (viruses, bacteria, fungi, protozoa)
- CAN spread from person to person
- Examples: Cold, flu, COVID-19, tuberculosis, athlete's foot, malaria

**NON-INFECTIOUS diseases:**
- Caused by genetics, lifestyle, or environmental factors (NOT pathogens)
- CANNOT spread from person to person
- Examples: Diabetes, cancer, asthma, heart disease, arthritis

**Person A has a cold (caused by a virus)** ‚Üí infectious ‚Üí you can catch it through droplets when they sneeze

**Person B has diabetes (caused by genetic/lifestyle factors)** ‚Üí non-infectious ‚Üí you cannot "catch" it from them

**The air conditioning myth:** Air conditioning doesn't kill germs (though HEPA filters can help trap some particles). Diseases spread through direct/indirect contact, droplets, or airborne particles.

stages.title: The Four Pathogen Types
stages.description: Not all pathogens are created equal. They vary in size, structure, how they reproduce, and what they attack. Let's build a rogue's gallery of our enemies.

sections.heading: ü¶† BACTERIA (Prokaryotes)
sections.content:
**SIZE:** 0.5-5 micrometers (Œºm) ‚Äî tiny, but visible under microscope

**STRUCTURE:**
- Single-celled organisms
- NO nucleus (DNA floats freely in cell)
- Cell wall (different from plant cell walls)
- Can have flagella (tail for movement)

**HOW THEY CAUSE DISEASE:**
- Reproduce rapidly (some double every 20 minutes!)
- Produce toxins that damage host cells
- Examples: Strep throat (Streptococcus), food poisoning (Salmonella), tuberculosis

**IMPORTANT:** Most bacteria are HARMLESS or HELPFUL!
- Gut bacteria help digest food
- Nitrogen-fixing bacteria help plants grow
- Only a small percentage cause disease

**TREATMENT:** ANTIBIOTICS (drugs that kill bacteria or stop their reproduction)

sections.heading: üß¨ VIRUSES (Not Alive!)
sections.content:
**SIZE:** 20-400 nanometers (nm) ‚Äî 10-100x SMALLER than bacteria!

**STRUCTURE:**
- NOT a cell (no cytoplasm, no organelles, no metabolism)
- Just genetic material (DNA or RNA) wrapped in a protein coat
- Cannot reproduce on their own

**HOW THEY CAUSE DISEASE:**
- Hijack living cells like pirates
- Inject genetic material into host cell
- Force host cell to make copies of the virus
- Host cell bursts, releasing new viruses
- Examples: Cold, flu, COVID-19, measles, HIV, chickenpox

**ARE VIRUSES ALIVE?** Debatable!
- NO: Can't reproduce alone, no metabolism, no cells
- YES: Contain genetic information, evolve, reproduce (with help)
- Most scientists say: "Not technically alive, but not NOT alive either"

**TREATMENT:** ANTIVIRALS (limited options), VACCINES (prevention), or just wait it out (immune system fights them)

sections.heading: üçÑ FUNGI (More Than Mushrooms)
sections.content:
**SIZE:** Varies ‚Äî single cells (yeasts) to large multicellular (mushrooms)

**STRUCTURE:**
- Eukaryotic cells (have nucleus)
- Cell wall made of chitin (different from plants)
- Some are single-celled (yeast), some form networks (mold)

**HOW THEY CAUSE DISEASE:**
- Grow ON or IN host tissues
- Absorb nutrients from host
- Examples: Athlete's foot (tinea), ringworm, thrush (yeast infection), mold allergies

**IMPORTANT:** Most fungi are helpful!
- Decompose dead material (recycle nutrients)
- Make bread rise (yeast)
- Produce penicillin (antibiotic comes from fungus!)

**TREATMENT:** ANTIFUNGALS (creams, pills that kill fungi without harming human cells)

sections.heading: ü¶é PROTOZOA (Single-Celled Predators)
sections.content:
**SIZE:** 10-50 Œºm (larger than bacteria)

**STRUCTURE:**
- Single-celled eukaryotes (have nucleus)
- Can move using flagella, cilia, or pseudopods
- More complex than bacteria

**HOW THEY CAUSE DISEASE:**
- Live in host tissues (blood, intestines, brain)
- Feed on host cells or nutrients
- Examples: Malaria (Plasmodium), giardia (diarrhea), amoebic dysentery

**IMPORTANT:**
- Often spread by contaminated water or insect vectors (mosquitoes)
- More common in tropical/subtropical regions
- Many are harmless and live in water/soil

**TREATMENT:** ANTIPROTOZOALS (specific drugs for each type)

activities.title: Spot the Pathogen Myths
activities.scenario: The Bio-Defense Agency has intercepted several false reports from unreliable sources. Your mission: Identify and correct the misconceptions about pathogens.
activities.task: Find and correct FOUR common misconceptions about pathogens.

errors.errorText: All bacteria cause disease and should be eliminated with antibacterial products.
errors.correction:
**MYTH!** Most bacteria are harmless or beneficial:
- Gut bacteria (microbiome) help digest food, produce vitamins, train immune system
- Nitrogen-fixing bacteria in soil help plants grow
- Bacteria in sewage treatment break down waste

**Only ~1% of bacteria species cause disease.** Overuse of antibacterial products can kill helpful bacteria and promote antibiotic resistance.

**Better approach:** Good hygiene (handwashing), not sterilization of everything.
errors.misconception: Thinking all bacteria are dangerous pathogens

errors.errorText: Antibiotics kill all germs, including viruses and fungi, so they should be used for colds and flu.
errors.correction:
**MYTH!** Antibiotics ONLY kill BACTERIA:
- They target bacterial cell walls or bacterial ribosomes
- Viruses have NO cell wall and NO ribosomes
- Fungi have different cell walls (chitin, not peptidoglycan)

**Using antibiotics for viral infections:**
- Doesn't help (virus isn't affected)
- Wastes resources
- Causes side effects (diarrhea, allergic reactions)
- Promotes antibiotic resistance in bacteria

**Colds and flu are caused by VIRUSES** ‚Üí antibiotics won't work ‚Üí rest and symptom management instead.

**MYTH!** Viruses and bacteria are COMPLETELY DIFFERENT:

**BACTERIA:**
- Living cells (metabolism, can reproduce independently)
- 0.5-5 Œºm (micrometers)
- Prokaryotic (no nucleus)

**VIRUSES:**
- NOT cells (no metabolism, can't reproduce alone)
- 20-400 nm (nanometers) ‚Äî 10-100x SMALLER
- Not even clearly "alive"

**Viruses are not a subcategory of bacteria** ‚Äî they're a completely separate type of pathogen with a totally different structure and life strategy.
errors.misconception: Thinking viruses are just tiny bacteria

errors.errorText: If you can't see it, you can't catch it. Pathogens are visible to the naked eye.
errors.correction:
**MYTH!** All pathogens are MICROSCOPIC:
- Viruses: 20-400 nm (need electron microscope)
- Bacteria: 0.5-5 Œºm (need light microscope)
- Fungi: Some visible (mold), some microscopic (yeast)
- Protozoa: 10-50 Œºm (need microscope)

**You CANNOT see pathogens without a microscope.** This is why:
- Handwashing is important (you can't see if germs are on your hands)
- Food can look fine but be contaminated
- Sick people may not look sick (asymptomatic carriers)

**Visible things (dirt, dust) may or may not contain pathogens.** Clean-looking hands can still carry viruses.
errors.misconception: Thinking pathogens are visible without magnification

stages.title: Pathogen Identification Lab
stages.description: Time to put your knowledge to work. Can you correctly identify pathogens from their characteristics and choose the right treatment?

activities.title: Pathogen Identification: Match Characteristics to Treatment
activities.instructions: Match each pathogen description to its correct classification and treatment. Understanding these patterns is critical for choosing the right medical intervention.

pairs.definition: VIRUS ‚Äî treat with ANTIVIRALS or supportive care

stages.title: Build Your Rogue's Gallery
stages.description: Create a reference guide summarizing the four pathogen types. This will be your go-to resource for identifying threats.

activities.title: Choose Your Final Challenge
activities.description: Demonstrate your pathogen expertise by completing one of these missions:

options.title: Comparison Table
options.description: Create a detailed comparison table with columns: Pathogen Type | Size | Structure | How it Causes Disease | Examples | Treatment. Include all four types (bacteria, viruses, fungi, protozoa).

options.title: Disease Detective Case
options.description: You're given symptoms and lab results for a mystery disease. Use the clues to identify: (1) Is it infectious or non-infectious? (2) What type of pathogen? (3) What treatment? Write your diagnostic reasoning.

options.title: Antibiotic Resistance PSA
options.description: Create a public service announcement explaining why people shouldn't demand antibiotics for viral infections. Include: what antibiotics do, why they don't work on viruses, and the danger of antibiotic resistance.
